stories.title: Astronomers investigate open cluster Messier 37 and its surroundings

stories.text:
HI! Looking for a no-code SaaS solution with really good UI for a non-technical person to upload a file and extract structured data. The files are likely to be in TXT, CSV, or Excel format. Files will yield multiple rows of data, so the UI should make it relatively easy to identify the pattern/structure of fields, and then allow the user execute parsing, compare the resulting structured data against what the user sees, and iterate until it's solid.

I swear in the last month or so that such a product appeared on HN, but I've spent an hour combing thru browser history and searching HN, with no luck. I think I saw it on my phone using one of the popular HN apps that uses an embedded web browser, so there is no "history" feature.
stories.title: Ask HN: No-Code SaaS for parsing files

stories.text:
We hear of algorithms handing down sentencing guidelines. On the other spectrum it is more apparent that the Supreme Court in the US is political and biased.

Politicians pass huge bills they likely have not read.

How could the current state of art AI/ML improve things in these areas?
stories.title: Ask HN: AI Improve Lawmaking and Justice?
